isis.stitle: DIAGNOSTIC TROUBLE CODES - Terms and Definitions

svcsubproc.title: 1. Switches In An Invalid State
svcsubproc.para: In order to understand this phrase you must understand the construction of the center panel switches used on NGV. There are two "fingers" that protrude out of the back of the switch actuators (an upper and lower finger). These fingers are used to depress microswitches located on the circuit board of the center panel switch modules. With two microswitches there are 4 possible states for a switch to be in:

item.para: Both microswitches depressed (this is always an illegal switch state, there is no switch actuator that depresses both microswitches simultaneously).

svcsubproc.para: There are 4 different switch actuation types used on NGV:

step1.para: Monostable 2 position-An example of this type of actuator is Marker Interrupt. For the marker interrupt example, the switch is stable in the down position (upper finger depressing upper microswitch) and is momentary in the up position (lower finger depressing lower microswitch). If both of the microswitches are depressed simultaneously or neither is depressed this is an invalid state and will cause a trouble code to be set.

Monostable 3 position-An example of this type of actuator is Panel Light Dimmer. For the panel dimmer example, the switch is stable in the center position (neither microswitche depressed) and is momentary in the up position (lower finger depressing lower microswitch) and down position (upper finger depressing upper microswitch). Both microswitches depressed simultaneously is an invalid state.

Tristable 3 position-An example of this type of actuator is Engine Brake. For the engine brake example, the switch is stable in the up (lower finger depressing lower microswitch), middle (neither microswitche depressed) and down positions (upper finger depressing upper microswitch). Both microswitches depressed simultaneously is an invalid state.

Bistable 2 position-An example of this type of actuator is Fog Light. For the fog light example, the switch is stable in the up (lower finger depressing lower microswitch) and down positions (upper finger depressing upper microswitch). If both of the microswitches are depressed simultaneously or neither is depressed this is an invalid state and will cause a trouble code to be set.

svcsubproc.title: 2. Under Current
svcsubproc.para: This term is used to describe the ESC virtual fuse output faults. As the DTC list states, this corresponds to less than 1/2 Amp being drawn on this output. In other words, less current is being drawn on this output than expected by the ESC.

svcsubproc.title: 3. Over current
svcsubproc.para: This term is used to describe the ESC virtual fuse outputs and the Remote Power Module fuse faults. There are two types of output devices used on the ESC, a 20 Amp and a 10 Amp device. The Remote Power Module only uses the 20 Amp device. The 20 Amp devices behave like a 20 Amp circuit breaker and the 10 Amp devices behave like a 10 Amp circuit breaker. Over current means that sufficient current has been drawn from the output to cause the "circuit breaker" to trip.

svcsubproc.title: 4. Out of range high
svcsubproc.para: This means that the signal is outside its normal operating range on the high side. For example, the input pin on the ESC which is attached to the clutch switch has a normal operating voltage range of 12% to 18% of ignition voltage. Out of range high would correspond to a value greater than 18% of ignition voltage on this pin.

svcsubproc.title: 5. Out of range low
svcsubproc.para: This means that the signal is outside its normal operating range on the low side. For example, the input pin on the ESC which is attached to the clutch switch has a normal operating voltage range of 12% to 18% of ignition voltage. Out of range low would correspond to a value less than 12% of ignition voltage on this pin.

svcsubproc.title: 8. Short to ground
svcsubproc.para: This means that the ESC pin that the trouble code is generated for is connected to chassis ground

svcsubproc.title: 9. Overload
svcsubproc.para: An overload corresponds to too much load current. For example, for the virtual fuse outputs if too much load (i.e. too many lamps connected to this output) are attached to this output the device will trip.

svcsubproc.title: 10. Open circuit
svcsubproc.para: Open circuit means that there is no load attached to the output. For example, a broken wire (or disconnected connector) from the ESC to the fog lights will generate an open circuit fault.
